folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
36 Ericsson Place (formerly Beach Street), south side, between Varick and Hudson Street's, showing the home of Capt. John Ericsson of Civil War fame(the Monitor). This portion of Beach Street was changed to Ericsson Place in 1939, to honor and commemorate his achievements.

About 1905

Gift of Urbrock Collection

folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
36 Ericsson Place (formerly Beach Street), south side, between Varick and Hudson Street's, showing the home of Capt. John Ericsson of Civil War (the Monitor) fame. In 1939 this portion of Beach Street was changed to honor and commemorate his achievements.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Varick Street, east side, between Beach and Laight Streets, showing the front of St. John's Chapel, P.E. The railing here shown, was brought from England. The church has been demolished and on its site stands now (1937) station V of the United States Post Office. For a rear view of the Church, see York Street, west from West Broadway to St. Johns Lane.
About 1914.
Gift of Samuel Landsman.

(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the front entrance.
About 1914.
Gift of Samuel Landsman.

(3)
A portion of the same, showing the gate to the south church yard.
About 1914.
Gift of Samuel Landsman.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Varick Street, east side, at Beach Street. Also shown is No. 19 Beach Street, adjoining the N.E. (empty lot) corner of Varick Street. The 10-story warehouse shown on the left, is No. 30-32 Varick Street, and has an ell, No. 17-11 Beach Street.

April 2, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Beach Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Beach Street, east from and including Varick Street, to and including West Broadway. The New York Telephone Building is shown in the background.
June 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The Same, as seen from Hudson Street and across the clearance where the former New York Central Freight Depot stood.
November 27, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2. Buildings shown in the foreground are on the east side of Varick Street and include both the N.E. & S.E. corners of Beach Street.
November 27, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
24 Varick Street, at the S.E. corner of Beach Street. Also shown are Nos. 14, 12 and 10 Beach Street, at, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Varick Street. The new 3-story building at the corner, is also known as No. 14 Beach Street.

About 1935.

Louis H. Dreyer.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
24 Varick Street, at the S.E. corner of Beach Street.. Note on the left, the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on West Broadway.

About 1935.

Louis H. Dreyer.

folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Ericsson Place, (Beach Street) north side, west from Varick Street. Shown under demolition, is the old New York Central Freight Depot.

September 17, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Varick Street, west side, north from Ericsson Place (Beach Street). Shown in the foreground, is the New York Central Freight Depot, (known as St. John's Park Freight Station) under demolition. September 17, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, several weeks later. October 21, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view westward, thru the center of demolition. September 17, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Varick Street, east side, at Beach Street, as seen from Hudson Street, and across the former site of the New York Central Freight Depot. The small 3-story building on the right, is the 4th Precinct Police Station, and is at the S.W. corner of Ericsson Place (Beach Street).

December 5, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
20 to 42 Ericsson Place (Beach Street) south side, west from but not including Varick (left) to Hudson (right) Streets, as seen across clearance (former site of St. John's Depot) at the N.E. corner of Hudson Street and Ericsson Place. The small white building (No. 20) on the extreme left is the 4th Precinct Police Station and is at the S.W. corner of Varick Street. Shown on the right is an extensive view southward on Hudson Street from Light Street. John Ericsson, the inventor and builder of the famous war-vessel "Monitor" resided at one time at what was No. 30 Beach Street and in his honor this portion which contained his house has been named Ericsson Place. The site would be in the center, directly in front of the chimney tower shown.

May 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
